diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can present with nephritis, proteinuria, autoimmune hemolysis, neurological manifestations (including psychosis), and skin manifestations such as follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can exhibit features of various connective tissue diseases including SLE, presenting with nephritis, proteinuria, and neurological symptoms. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia can occasionally be seen.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though arthritis is the primary feature, secondary Sjögren's can lead to systemic manifestations including nephritis and neurologic symptoms. Follicular hyperkeratosis and autoimmune hemolysis are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory condition primarily affects skin and muscles but can have systemic involvement. Skin manifestations could theoretically include follicular hyperkeratosis; nephritis, and rarely, auto-immune hemolysis may occur.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can cause nephritis and proteinuria due to kidney involvement. Neuropsychiatric symptoms are possible but less common. Autoimmune hemolysis is rare but skin manifestations like livedo reticularis could be confused with follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects exocrine glands but can have renal (nephritis, proteinuria) and hematologic (autoimmune hemolysis) manifestations. Neurological involvement can manifest as psychosis in rare cases.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the skin and joints, in rare cases, it can present with kidney issues (nephritis, proteinuria) and neurological symptoms. Hematological manifestations like autoimmune hemolysis are uncommon.

diagnoses.name: Schizophrenia
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily a psychiatric disorder with psychosis. The other symptoms would not be directly related but could co-occur due to unrelated renal and hematological disorders or severe neglect of personal health.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.rationale: Mainly a liver disorder, but can present with features like hyperkeratosis due to xerosis. Autoimmune hemolysis, nephritis, and proteinuria can be secondary complications in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with systemic symptoms including autoimmune hemolysis, renal involvement (nephritis, proteinuria), and rarely cutaneous manifestations or neurological symptoms including psychosis.

diagnoses: Kidney diseases leading to nephrotic syndrome
Drug Reactions (e.g., reactions to medications or illicit drugs that can cause these symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

reasoning: Mood lability and attention deficit can be associated with the high cortisol levels found in Cushing's Syndrome.
Striae (stretch marks) are a hallmark sign, typically wide, and purple or red in color, resulting from the overproduction of cortisol.
Sinusitis isn't directly related but could occur as an incidental finding or due to a weakened immune system.
Produces excess cortisol leading to symptoms like mood lability, striae, and potentially attention deficit.
Sinutitis and irritated eyes aren't direct symptoms but could be secondary effects of immune system compromise or treatment side effects.
While not directly explaining all symptoms, the presence of striae might suggest connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.
Attention deficit and mood lability are not common symptoms but might be coincidental or related to the psychological impact.
Irritated eyes and sinusitis could point towards an allergic response.
Mood lability and attention deficit may be observed as secondary effects due to the discomfort and chronic nature of the allergy.
Striae and mood lability can occur in PCOS due to hormonal imbalances.
Sinusitis and irritated eyes are not directly related but could occur coincidentally.
Mood lability and attention deficit are commonly seen in patients suffering from poor sleep quality due to sleep apnea.
Sinusitis could be secondary due to chronic snoring and airway irritation.
Mood lability and attention deficit are common in depression.
Striae may appear as physical manifestations of significant weight changes; however, sinusitis and irritated eyes are not directly related.
Striae, mood lability, and potentially attention deficit could be observed in individuals with significant obesity.
Irritated eyes and sinusitis could be unrelated, incidental findings.
Characterized by mood lability, and may indirectly affect attention span.
Sinusitis, striae, and irritated eyes are not classic symptoms but could be associated with lifestyle factors or comorbid conditions.
Can cause mood lability and attention issues due to the overactivity of the thyroid gland.
Striae are not typically seen in hyperthyroidism, but sinusitis and irritated eyes could be related to the general hyperactive state or autoimmune process (as in Graves' disease).

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including severe headaches, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. Can also include episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include weakness, tingling, and in some cases, muscle spasms or spasticity.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Symptoms may include episodic weakness and possibly contribute to conditions like POTS.

diagnoses.name: Mitochondrial Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that occur when mitochondria fail to produce enough energy for cell or organ function, which can present as episodic weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms that occur when there is damage to nerves that regulate nonvoluntary body functions, including heart rate, blood pressure, and digestion. This can relate closely to POTS.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the inflammation of the lining of your arteries. Symptoms can include pain in the face or jaw, sometimes associated with oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Benign Essential Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A movement disorder that causes the eyelids to close involuntarily, referred to as blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Functional Gastrointestinal Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder that affects the functioning of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to symptoms such as nausea and vomiting without a clear structural or biochemical cause.

diagnoses: Thyroid Disorders, including Hypothyroidism and Hyperthyroidism
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Common cold or viral respiratory infection

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Aphasia and numbness can be part of a complex migraine aura.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and numbness, typically on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is characterized by temporary stroke-like symptoms such as aphasia and numbness, but usually lasts only a few minutes to hours without permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause headaches, speech difficulties like aphasia, and numbness or weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like numbness, weakness, balance issues, and in some cases, language difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include a severe headache, stiff neck, phonophobia, and in severe cases, neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, causing symptoms like headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and in some cases, speech and sensory issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Post-seizure, patients may experience headache, numbness, and temporary aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to infection, causing symptoms like headache, fever, vomiting, and in advanced stages, neurological deficits such as aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where individuals experience a temporary weakness on one side of their body (hemiplegia) in addition to the traditional migraine symptoms. This can also include sensory symptoms like numbness and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing inflammation and potentially debilitating physical and cognitive effects.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. This condition can be life-threatening due to the inflammation's proximity to the brain and spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. The abscess can cause a range of symptoms including headache, fever, weakness, and changes in vision.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A group of eye conditions that can cause blindness by damaging a nerve at the back of your eye called the optic nerve. Symptoms may include blurred vision, eye pain, headache, and seeing halos around lights.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, typically the large and medium arteries of the head. It can cause headaches, jaw muscle pain when eating, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. This can cause weakness and tiredness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms may include headaches, weakness, seizures, and problems with vision like scotoma or blurred vision.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: A condition that produces severe headaches on one side of the head. It is often accompanied by watering of the eye and a stuffy nose. Symptoms can include sensitivity to light.
